action.action-desc: Mr. Good of Virginia (for himself, Mrs. Miller of Illinois, Mr. LaMalfa, and Mr. Biggs) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Education and the Workforce

form.official-title: To establish a private right of action for parents with respect to the teaching of racial discrimination theory and other actions by covered schools, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Empowering Parents Act.

paragraph.text: The family unit consisting of a mother, father, and child is the foundation of civil society.
The rights and authority of parents are God-given and self-evident.
The rights and authority of parents do not derive from the government.
The rights and authority of parents should not be challenged or undermined by the government, but must be preserved and protected.
Parents are responsible for impressing faith, morals, and values upon their children; such responsibility does not belong to teachers, school board members, or politicians.
No teacher, school board member, or public official has the right to politicize or indoctrinate children.
More than 70 percent of citizens of the United States support the ability of parents to choose where students attend school.

It is contrary to the 10th Amendment of the Constitution and the principles of federalism espoused by the founding fathers for the Federal Government to supersede State or local authorities regarding the instruction and testing of students.
Taxpayers have a right to know what publicly funded schools are teaching students.

section.text: It is the sense of Congress that—

paragraph.text: a covered school should not—

subparagraph.text: deny a student the ability to attend school in person;
intentionally expose a student to racial discrimination theory;
intentionally expose a student to radical gender theory or sexually explicit content;
require a biological woman to compete against a biological man in an athletic competition hosted or sponsored by such school;
require a biological woman and a biological man to share a private facility, including—
require a student to abide by a health mandate without first obtaining parental consent or require, as a prerequisite for in-person school attendance—

paragraph.text: a covered school should—

subparagraph.text: protect the personal information of every student, as required under section 444 of the General Education Provisions Act (commonly known as the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act of 1974 ) (20 U.S.C. 1232g); and
be parent-led and locally managed with State oversight;

paragraph.text: Federal law enforcement agencies should not target a parent for exercising First Amendment rights on school property or in school board meetings; and
a parent should have the ability to choose the school that the children of such parent attend.
compel a teacher or student to adopt, affirm, adhere to, or profess—

subparagraph.text: any academic discipline, program, or activity that is premised on the idea that—

clause.text: the United States is a Nation founded on White supremacy and oppression, or that these forces are at the root of American society;
one race or sex is inherently superior to another race or sex;
the United States is fundamentally racist or sexist;
an individual, by virtue of his or her race or sex, is inherently racist, sexist, or oppressive, whether consciously or unconsciously;
an individual should be discriminated against or receive adverse treatment solely or partly because of his or her race or sex;
members of one race or sex cannot and should not attempt to treat others without respect to race or sex;
an individual’s moral character is necessarily determined by his or her race or sex;
an individual, by virtue of his or her race or sex, bears responsibility for actions committed in the past by other members of the same race or sex;
any individual should feel discomfort, guilt, anguish, or any other form of psychological distress on account of his or her race or sex; or
meritocracy or traits such as a hard work ethic are racist or sexist, or were created by a particular race to oppress another race; or

subparagraph.text: an idea, where such compulsion violates title IV or title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 (42 U.S.C. 2000c et seq.);

paragraph.text: compel a student to observe or espouse obscene or sexual materials without the consent of a parent of such student;

instruct or require an employee of such school to refer to a student using a pronoun not associated with the biological sex of such student, without obtaining consent to do so from a parent of such student;
act as the agent of a parent of a student enrolled in such school, for purposes of—

subparagraph.text: receiving a notice or other information required to be provided to a parent of such student; or

paragraph.text: neglect to report sexual assault or sexual harassment on school property to the appropriate law enforcement authorities.

subsection.text: Nothing in this section may be construed to prohibit a teacher or a student from discussing public policy issues or matters of public debate.
A parent aggrieved by a violation of section 4 may commence a civil action against the covered school responsible for the violation.
In any action under subsection (a), the court may award appropriate relief, including—

paragraph.text: temporary, preliminary, or permanent injunctive relief;
compensatory damages;
punitive or exemplary damages; and
reasonable fees for attorneys.

subsection.text: An action under this section shall be brought not later than 30 days after the date on which the violation of section 4 occurred.

In a case in which a parent commences a civil action under subsection (a), the Attorney General shall have the exclusive authority to oversee, as appropriate, any investigation conducted by the Federal Government in connection with such action.

paragraph.text: The term biological man means an individual who is recognized as a male on the date of the birth of such individual, based on the genetic and reproductive biological characteristics of such individual.
The term biological sex means the sex recognized on the date of birth of the individual based on the genetic and reproductive biological characteristics of such individual.

The term biological woman means an individual who is recognized as a female on the date of the birth of such individual, based on the genetic and reproductive biological characteristics of such individual.
The term covered school means an elementary school or secondary school, as such terms are defined in section 8101 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 7801).
The term obscene material means material that, considered as a whole—

clause.text: a shameful or morbid interest in nudity, sexual conduct, sexual excitement, excretory functions or products thereof, or sadomasochistic abuse;

subparagraph.text: goes substantially beyond customary limits of candor in description or representation of the matters described in clause (A)(ii); and
does not have serious literary, artistic, political, or scientific value.

paragraph.text: The term parent has the meaning given such term in section 8101 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 7801).
